page.title: 2019 World Women's Handball Championship – European qualification

revision.text:
The European qualification for the [[2019 World Women's Handball Championship]], in [[Japan]], are played over two rounds.{{cite web|url=http://www.eurohandball.com/article/030958|title=Women's World Championship 2019 Qualification groups to be drawn at EHF Congress|date=18 June 2018|work=eurohandball.com}} In the first round of qualification, 16 teams who are not participating at the [[2018 European Women's Handball Championship|2018 European Championship]] were split into four groups. Each winner from four groups and the best 2nd-placed team will join remaining 13 teams from the European Championship to play a play-offs to determine nine qualifiers. ==Qualification phase 1== ===Seeding=== The draw was held on 24 June 2016.{{cite web|url=http://www.eurohandball.com/article/030969|title=Women's World Championship 2019 Qualification drawn in Glasgow|date=19 June 2018|work=eurohandball.com}} The winner from each group and the best second-ranked team advance to the play-off round. Each group played their matches in a mini-tournament at a pre-selected location.{{cite web|url=http://www.eurohandball.com/article/031042|title=Home rights drawn for Women’s World Championship 2019 qualification tournaments|date=17 July 2018|work=eurohandball.com}} {| class="wikitable" |- !width=15%|Pot 1 !width=15%|Pot 2 !width=15%|Pot 3 |- |valign="top"|{{hbw|BLR}}

{{other uses}} {{coord|39|59|35|N|46|55|50|E|display=title}} {{Infobox settlement |official_name = Ağdam
Ակնա, ''Akna'' |image_skyline = Juma Mosque Agdam1.JPG |pushpin_map = Azerbaijan |pushpin_mapsize = 300 |subdivision_type = Country |subdivision_name = {{Plainlist}} * {{flag|Azerbaijan}} (''[[de jure]]'') * {{flag|Artsakh}} (''[[de facto]]'') |subdivision_type1 = [[Administrative divisions of Azerbaijan|Rayon]] |subdivision_name1 = [[Agdam District|Agdam]] |leader_title = |leader_name = |established_title = |established_date = |area_total_km2 = |area_footnotes = |population_as_of = |population_total = |population_density_km2 = auto |timezone = |utc_offset = +4 |timezone_DST = |utc_offset_DST = +5 |coordinates = {{coord|39|59|35|N|46|55|50|E|region:AZ|display=inline}} |elevation_m = 369 |area_code = |website = }} '''Ağdam''' (also spelled '''Agdam''' or '''Aghdam''') is a [[ghost town]] in the southwest part of [[Azerbaijan]] and the formal capital of its [[Agdam District]], today controlled by the [[Republic of Artsakh|de facto Republic of Artsakh]]. Founded in the early 19th century, it grew considerably during the Soviet period and had 28,000 inhabitants by 1989. Armenian forces [[Battle of Aghdam|captured Agdam]] in July 1993 during the [[Nagorno-Karabakh War]].{{cite news|title=Caucasus City Falls to Armenian Forces|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1993/08/24/world/caucasus-city-falls-to-armenian-forces.html|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=24 August 1993|quote=In July, Armenian forces forced out the defenders of Agdam, Azerbaijan.}} The heavy fighting forced the entire population to flee eastwards. Upon seizing the city, [[Nagorno-Karabakh Republic]] (NKR) forces destroyed much of the town to discourage Azerbaijanis from returning. More damage occurred in the following decades when locals looted the abandoned town for building materials. It is currently almost entirely ruined and uninhabited.{{cite news|last1=Specter|first1=Michael|authorlink1=Michael Specter|title=Azerbaijan, Potentially Rich, Is Impoverished by Warfare|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/06/02/world/azerbaijan-potentially-rich-is-impoverished-by-warfare.html?pagewanted=all|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=2 June 1994|quote=Cities like Agdam have been emptied of people.}} In November 2010 it was renamed by the NKR government to '''Akna''' ({{lang-hy|Ակնա}}).{{cite news|title=Armenian separatists rename Azeri town|url=http://www.azernews.az/azerbaijan/26472.html|work=azernews.az|date=3 November 2010}}{{cite news|title=July 23 marks 21st anniv. of Akna (Aghdam) liberation|url=http://www.panarmenian.net/eng/foreign/news/180991/|agency=[[PanARMENIAN.Net]]|date=23 July 2014}} It is administratively part of the town of [[Askeran (town)|Askeran]], which is located some 10 km away.{{cite web|last1=Musayelyan|first1=Lusine|title=Life Among Ruins of Caucasus' Hiroshima|url=https://iwpr.net/global-voices/life-among-ruins-caucasus-hiroshima|publisher=[[Institute for War and Peace Reporting]]|date=26 April 2011}} ==Etymology== The city's name is of [[Azerbaijani language|Azerbaijani]] origin and means "white house", where ''{{lang|az|ağ}}'' means "white" and ''{{lang|az|dam}}'' is "house" or "attic", thus referring to a "bright sun-lit, white house" which was given by [[Panah Ali Khan]] of the [[Karabakh Khanate]].{{cite web|title=Agdam city |url=http://www.mct.gov.az/?/en/cities/view/291/ |publisher=[[Ministry of Culture and Tourism (Azerbaijan)|Ministry of Culture and Tourism of Azerbaijan]] |accessdate=26 July 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120720031731/http://www.mct.gov.az/?%2Fen%2Fcities%2Fview%2F291%2F |archivedate=20 July 2012 |deadurl=no |df= }} Another possibility is that it was derived from ancient [[Turkic languages|Turkic]] glossary meaning "small fortress". In the distant past, Turkic speaking tribes built small fortresses for their protection and safety. ==History== [[File:Agdam mosque.jpg|thumb|left|200px|[[Agdam Mosque]] on Azerbaijani stamp (depicted as it looked before the Karabakh war)]] Agdam was founded in the 18th century and granted city status in 1828.{{cite web|script-title=ru:Значение слова "Агдам" в Большой Советской Энциклопедии|url=http://bse.sci-lib.com/article107063.html|publisher=[[Soviet Encyclopedia]]|accessdate=26 July 2010|language=ru}} It is {{convert|26|km|abbr=in}} from [[Stepanakert]] ([[Khankendi]]). Before the [[Nagorno-Karabakh War]], butter, wine and [[brandy]], machine factories and a railway station functioned there.{{cite web|script-title=ru:Агдам (Азербайджан) |url=http://www.landmarkers.ru/sec9/pos2752 |website=Landmarkers.ru |accessdate=26 July 2010 |language=ru |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120309213756/http://www.landmarkers.ru/sec9/pos2752 |archivedate=9 March 2012 |df= }}{{cite web|last=Girchenko|first=Yuriy|script-title=ru:Юрий Гирченко. В Союзе все спокойно...|url=http://lib.misto.kiev.ua/MEMUARY/KARABAH/girchenko.txt|accessdate=26 July 2010|language=ru}} ===Nagorno-Karabakh War=== {{main|Nagorno-Karabakh War}} [[File:Aghdam_6.jpg|thumb|Nature slowly reclaiming the ruins]] Agdam was the scene of fierce fighting during the [[Nagorno-Karabakh War]]. According to journalist Robert Parsons, Azerbaijani forces used Agdam as a base for attacks on Karabakh, launching [[BM-21 Grad]] missiles and bombing raids from there against civilians.{{cite news|last=Parsons |first=Robert |title=Tug-of-war for Nagorno-Karabakh |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/programmes/from_our_own_correspondent/775655.stm |accessdate=26 July 2010 |publisher=[[BBC News]] |date=3 June 2000 |archivedate=27 April 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100427155501/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/programmes/from_our_own_correspondent/775655.stm |deadurl=no |df= }} During the [[Battle of Aghdam]], Armenian forces violated the rules of war by hostage-taking, indiscriminate fire, and the forcible displacement of civilians.Human Rights Watch. ''Azerbaijan: Seven years of conflict in Nagorno-Karabakh''. p.19. As the city fell, almost its entire population fled eastward.{{cite web|last=Paul |first=Amanda |title=Agdam – an Azerbaijani ghost town |url=http://www.todayszaman.com/columnist-244251-agdam----an-azerbaijani-ghost-town.html |accessdate=18 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110519205653/http://www.todayszaman.com/columnist-244251-agdam----an-azerbaijani-ghost-town.html |archivedate=19 May 2011 |df= }} The [[Armed Forces of Armenia]] still use the city as a [[buffer zone]], meaning that Ağdam remains empty and decaying, and usually off-limits for [[tourism|sightseeing]].{{cite web|last=Hannigan |first=Chris |title=Ghost Towns: Ağdam, Azerbaijan |url=http://googlesightseeing.com/2010/01/ghost-towns-agdam-azerbaijan/ |accessdate=26 July 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100813235151/http://googlesightseeing.com/2010/01/ghost-towns-agdam-azerbaijan/ |archivedate=13 August 2010 |deadurl=no |df= }}{{cite web |last=Chauffor |first=Célia |title=Report: Agdam, ghost city |url=http://www.caucaz.com/home_eng/breve_contenu.php?id=55 |publisher=Caucaz Europenewz |accessdate=26 July 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100701011859/http://www.caucaz.com/home_eng/breve_contenu.php?id=55 |archivedate=1 July 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} ===Post-war years=== The ruined city once had a population of almost 40,000 people,{{cite web|url=http://pop-stat.mashke.org/azerbaijan-cities.htm|title=Azerbaijani cities}} but today it is an almost entirely uninhabited [[ghost town]].{{cite web|title=20 Abandoned Cities from Around the World|url=http://www.dailycognition.com/index.php/2008/08/30/20-abandoned-cities-from-around-the-world.html|work=Daily Cognition|accessdate=26 July 2010}} All the houses are ruined, some by shells fired in the war, others due to looting for building materials.{{cite news|last=Esslemont|first=Tom|title=Karabakh guns still at the ready|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/8117243.stm|accessdate=21 February 2018|publisher=BBC News|date=25 June 2009}}[http://www.aze.az/eng.php?id=17254 Armenians occupied Agdam cities listed among the ghosts] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706131004/http://www.aze.az/eng.php?id=17254 |date=2011-07-06 }} According to Azeri sources one of the buildings to be stripped of materials is the [[Agdam Mosque]], which has been converted into a barn for cattle and pigs. Its derelict condition, including a missing roof, drew criticism from Azerbaijani and Turkish communities, who wrote a letter in 2010 to [[Pope Benedict XVI]] asking him to warn Armenians (though Armenians predominantly follow a church which [[Armenian Apostolic Church#Miaphysitism versus monophysitism|broke with Rome]] in the 6th century) about the situation.{{cite web|title=Turks complain to Pope on vandalism in Karabakh mosque by Armenians |url=http://www.news.az/articles/19325 |accessdate=26 July 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100720025140/http://www.news.az/articles/19325 |archivedate=20 July 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} But according to Armenians the mosques in Karabakh are mostly perceived as an Iranian cultural heritage not Azerbaijani heritage and the mosque has never been used so. It is closed nowadays. Also, according to Artsakh republic authorities the roof of the mosque was restored. {{Wide image|Agdam_pano.jpg|2000px|align-cap=center|In 2008, the [[Lonely Planet]] guidebook dubbed the city as '''Ahmad ibn Sahl ibn Hashim''' (died 920) was an [[Iranian people|Iranian]] aristocrat who served the [[Saffarids]] and later the [[Samanids]].
==Biography== [[File:Transoxiana 8th century.svg|thumb|right|300px|Map of [[Khurasan]], [[Transoxiana]] and [[Tokharistan]]]] Ahmad belonged to a ''[[dehqan]]'' family of [[Merv]] known as the Kamkarian family, which claimed descent from the last [[Sasanian]] king, [[Yazdegerd III]]. Ahmad was the son of a certain Sahl, and had three unnamed brothers, who were later killed during a local struggle in Merv between Iranians and [[Arabs]]. Ahmad, in order to avenge his three brothers, revolted against his overlord, the Saffarid ruler [[Amr ibn al-Layth]] (r. 879–901), but was defeated and taken prisoner in [[Sistan]].{{sfn|Gibb|1967|p=278}} However, he managed to escape and then returned to Merv, where he captured the local governor [[Abu Ja'far Ghuri]] and proclaimed his adherence to Samanid ruler [[Isma'il ibn Ahmad]] (r. 892-907).{{sfn|Bosworth|1984|pp=643-644}} He shortly went to the Samanid court at [[Bukhara]] and quickly achieved prominence under Isma'il.
In 900 (or 901), Ismail defeated and captured Amr at [[Balkh]], and shortly conquered his territories in Khurasan, which Ahmad also played a role in. In ca. 902, Ahmad was appointed as the governor of the newly conquered province of [[Tabaristan]]. He later served as the commander of the army in [[Ray, Iran|Ray]] and also as leader of the personal guards of the Samanid prince who governed the city, [[Abu Salih Mansur]].{{sfn|Bosworth|2011|p=54}} During the reign of Isma'il's successor, [[Ahmad Samani]] (r. 907-914), Ahmad was sent in 910-11 along with other prominent Samanid officers to conquer Sistan.
During the reign of Ahmad's successor, [[Nasr II]] (r. 914-943), Ahmad was sent in 919 to suppress the rebellion of the governor of Khurasan, [[Husayn ibn Ali Marvarrudhi]], which he managed to accomplish.{{sfn|Bosworth|1984|pp=643-644}}{{sfn|Houtsma|1993|p=871}} Husayn was captured during the battle and was sent to Bukhara. After a few weeks, however, after being lied to by Nasr, who had been promising him a certain thing, Ahmad shortly rebelled at [[Nishapur]], made incursions into the Samanid city of [[Gorgan]], and managed to repel its governor Karategin.{{sfn|Houtsma|1993|p=872}} He then fortified himself in Merv to avoid a Samanid counter-attack. Nevertheless, the Samanid general [[Hamuya ibn Ali]] managed to lure Ahmad out of Merv and defeated him in a battle at [[Marw al-Rudh]]. Ahmad was captured during the battle and imprisoned in Bukhara, where he remained until his death in 920.

The '''Aloha Festivals''' are an annual series of free cultural celebrations observed in the state of [[Hawaii]] in the [[United States]]. It is the only statewide cultural festival in the nation. Highlights include the presentation of the Royal Court, a [[ho'olaule'a]] in [[Waikiki]], and the Floral Parade. Approximately 30,000 people volunteer to plan, organize, and provide labor for the Aloha Festivals each year. Their efforts entertain over 1,000,000 people from throughout the state and visitors from all over the world.
==History==
=== Establishment === In the spirit of preserving the [[Hawaiian culture]] and [[Cultural heritage|heritage]], the Aloha Festivals were established in 1946 as '''Aloha Week''' by former members of the local Junior Chamber of Commerce. The former manager of the festivals, [[Goriann Akau]], has said, "In 1946, after the war, Hawaiians needed an identity. We were lost and needed to regroup. When we started to celebrate our culture, we began to feel proud. We have a wonderful culture that had been buried for a number of years. This brought it out again. Self-esteem is more important than making a lot of money."<ref name="Foster2011">{{cite book|last=Foster|first=Jeanette|title=Frommer's Maui 2012|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aJB7ad5vqvEC&pg=PA31|accessdate=29 April 2012|date=7 July 2011|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=978-1-118-10069-1|page=31}}</ref>
=== Scaling down === The festival was celebrated on six of Hawaii's islands, but in 2008 festival organizers decided to hold most events on Oahu due to a lack of funding. There was also the chance that the Floral Parade would be cancelled altogether, but it was saved by private donors and funds from the [[Honolulu County, Hawaii|City and County of Honolulu]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.hawaiimagazine.com/blogs/hawaii_today/2009/9/19/Aloha_Festivals_Hawaii_parade_2009_schedule|title=Aloha Festivals 2009 ho‘olaulea block party, parade coming up. Here’s the schedule.|last=Char|first=Sherie|date=2009-09-19|work=Hawaii Magazine|access-date=2018-05-31|last2=Bailey|first2=Chris|language=en}}</ref>
== Events ==
=== Presentation of the Royal Court === The court is selected from a pool of applicants, all of whom must be of Hawaiian ancestry and of certain ages.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://thevoiceofkapolei.com/aloha-festivals-seeks-applicants-for-2016-oahu-royal-court-and-floral-parade/|title=Aloha Festivals Seeks Applicants for 2016 Oahu Royal Court and Floral Parade {{!}} The Voice of Kapolei|last=VOK|website=thevoiceofkapolei.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-05-31}}</ref> The festival itself begins with the presentation of the royal court during the opening ceremony. The ceremony takes place at [[Helumoa]], a section of Waikiki near the [[Royal Hawaiian Center]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.honolulumagazine.com/Honolulu-Magazine/September-2017/Your-Guide-to-the-2017-Aloha-Festivals-Opening-Ceremony/|title=Your Guide to the 2017 Aloha Festivals Celebrating Hawaiian Culture|access-date=2018-05-31|language=en}}</ref>
=== Floral Parade === The Floral Parade starts at the intersection of [[Hawaii Route 92|Ala Moana Boulevard]] and Kamakee st. and goes through [[Waikiki]] before finishing at [[Kapiolani Park]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.khon2.com/news/local-news/70th-annual-aloha-festivals-floral-parade-traffic-advisory-viewing-tips/901604671|title=70th annual Aloha Festivals Floral Parade traffic advisory, viewing tips|last=Inefuku|first=Terri|date=2016-09-21|work=KHON|access-date=2018-05-31|language=en-US}}</ref> The parade features [[Pa'u riders|p'au riders]], [[Marching band|marching bands]], [[Halau hula|hula halaus]], and that year's Aloha Festival Royal Court.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.halekulani.com/blog/celebrate-hawaiian-culture-aloha-festival|title=Celebrate Hawaiian Culture at the Aloha Festival|website=www.halekulani.com|language=en|access-date=2018-05-31}}</ref>
=== Ho'olaule'a === The [[Ho'olaule'a]] is a block party held in [[Waikiki]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/travel/deals/la-tr-hawaii-aloha-festivals-september-20170906-story.html|title=Where to find Aloha Festivals, Hawaii's biggest street parties, that last all of September|last=Jones|first=Jay|website=latimes.com|access-date=2018-05-31}}</ref> There is [[Music of Hawaii|Hawaiian music]], [[hula]], and food. Attendance is typically in the thousands.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.khon2.com/news/local-news/aloha-festivals-hoolaulea-to-close-kalakaua-ave-in-waikiki/901515715|title=Aloha Festivals hoolaulea to close Kalakaua Ave. in Waikiki|last=Inefuku|first=Terri|date=2017-09-22|work=KHON|access-date=2018-05-31|language=en-US}}</ref>
== Gallery ==
<gallery> File:US Army 51982 Aloha spirit on display at floral parade.jpg| File:US Army 51981 Aloha spirit on display at floral parade.jpg| File:US Army 51979 Aloha spirit on display at floral parade.jpg| </gallery>
==Themes== Each year has a specific theme:
* 2018: No Ke Kai Kakou E ("We are of the Sea")<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.travelweekly.com/Hawaii-Travel/Aloha-Festivals-adopts-theme-We-Are-of-the-Sea|title=Aloha Festivals adopts theme 'We Are of the Sea': Travel Weekly|last=Lavin|first=Tony|date=April 27, 2018|website=www.travelweekly.com|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-06-07}}</ref>
* 2016: ''Hāli‘a Aloha'' ("Treasured memories")
*2015: ''Hula Aloha'' ("Beloved Feather Treasures") *2010-14: ''?'' (info needed for these years) *2009: ''Hula'' ("Let the Story Be Told") *2008: ''Hula'' ("The Art of Hawaiian Dance") *2005: ''Nā Honu Hawai{{okina}}i'' ("The Spirit Within") *2004: ''No Nā Kamali{{okina}}i'' ("For the Children") *2003: ''E Mau Ana Ka Hula I Ke Kanaka'' ("Hula Lives Through Its People") *2002: ''Ka {{okina}}Uhane O Ka Loea'' ("The Spirit of the Masters") *2001: ''Ho{{okina}}ohanohano I Nā Holokai'' ("Honor the Voyagers") *2000: ''He Makana O Nā Lei Nani'' ("A Gift of Beautiful Leis") *1999: ''Hui Pū I ka Hula'' ("Together in Song and Dance") *1998: ''Ola Ka {{okina}}Ōiwi'' ("The Natives Endure")

{{Infobox military conflict |image= |caption= |conflict=Battle of Carchemish |partof=the Egyptian–Babylonian wars |date=c. 605 BC |place=[[Carchemish]] |result=Decisive [[Neo-Babylonian Empire|Babylonian]] and Median(?) victory. End of Egyptian intervention in the [[Near East]]. |combatant1=[[Late Period of ancient Egypt|Egypt]]
part of the army of the former [[Neo-Assyrian Empire|Assyria]] |combatant2=[[Neo-Babylonian Empire|Babylonia]]
Medes(?)[http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/media/ Encyclopedia Iranica] "After the fall of Ḥarran, the strategic center of Assyrian resistance was moved to Carchemish, a city on the Upper Euphrates, which at that time belonged to Egypt. Carchemish was captured by the Babylonians in 605 BCE. It is not clear whether the Medes also participated in this final defeat of the Assyrians" |commander1=[[Necho II]] |commander2=[[Nebuchadnezzar II]]
[[Cyaxares]](?) |strength1=40,000 |strength2=18,000 |casualties1=large |casualties2=minimal}} {{Campaignbox Campaigns of Nebuchadnezzar II}} The '''Battle of Carchemish''' was fought about 605 BC{{cite journal|last1=Horn|first1=Siegfried H|title=THE BABYLONIAN CHRONICLE AND THE ANCIENT CALENDAR OF THE KINGDOM OF JUDAH|journal=Andrews University Seminary Studies|date=1967|issue=5/1967|page=20|url=http://www.auss.info/auss_publication_file.php?pub_id=411&journal=1&type=pdf|accessdate=4 August 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150923180227/http://www.auss.info/auss_publication_file.php?pub_id=411&journal=1&type=pdf|archive-date=2015-09-23|dead-url=yes|df=}}{{cite book |last1=Wiseman |first1=D. J.|title=Chronicles of Chaldaean Kings (626-556 B.C.)|date=1956|publisher=British Museum Publications, Ltd.|location=British Museum|page=99}}{{cite web|last1=British Museum|title=Cuneiform tablet with part of the Babylonian Chronicle (605-594 BC)|website=britishmuseum.org|url=https://www.britishmuseum.org/explore/highlights/highlight_objects/me/c/cuneiform_nebuchadnezzar_ii.aspx|accessdate=4 August 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141030154541/https://www.britishmuseum.org/explore/highlights/highlight_objects/me/c/cuneiform_nebuchadnezzar_ii.aspx|archive-date=2014-10-30|dead-url=yes|df=}} between the armies of [[Late Period of ancient Egypt|Egypt]] allied with the remnants of the army of the former [[Neo-Assyrian Empire|Assyrian Empire]] against the armies of [[Neo-Babylonian Empire|Babylonia]], allied with the [[Medes]], [[Persian Empire|Persians]], and [[Scythians]]. ==Background== When the [[Assyria]]n capital [[Nineveh]] was [[Battle of Nineveh (612 BC)|overrun]] by the Medes, Scythians, Babylonians and their allies in 612 BC, the Assyrians moved their capital to [[Harran]]. When Harran was [[Fall of Harran|captured]] by the alliance in 609 BC,{{cite book|last=Grant|first=R.G.|title=Battle: A Visual Journey Through 5,000 Years of Combat |location=London |publisher=Dorling Kindersley|year=2005|pages=18}} remnants of the Assyrian army joined [[Carchemish]], a city under Egyptian rule, on the [[Euphrates]] river. Egypt (a former vassal of Assyria) was allied with the Assyrian king [[Ashur-uballit II]], and marched in 609 BC to his aid against the Babylonians.Georges Roux, ''Ancient Iraq'' The Egyptian army of Pharaoh [[Necho II]] was delayed at [[Battle of Megiddo (609 BC)|Megiddo]] by the forces of King [[Josiah]] of [[Kingdom of Judah|Judah]]. Josiah was killed, and his army was defeated at the [[Battle of Megiddo (609 BC)]]. The Egyptians and Assyrians together crossed the Euphrates and laid siege to Harran, which they failed to retake. They then retreated to north western Assyria (in what is today north eastern [[Syria]]). ==Battle== The Egyptians met the full might of the Babylonian and Median army led by [[Nebuchadnezzar II]] at Carchemish where the combined Egyptian and Assyrian forces were destroyed. Assyria ceased to exist as an independent power, and Egypt retreated and was no longer a significant force in the [[Ancient Near East]]. Babylonia reached its economic peak after 605 BC.King, Philip J., 1993 ''Jeremiah: An Archaeological Companion'', Westminster/John Knox Press p.22 [https://books.google.com/books?id=7xZ-HUcAEP8C&pg=PA22&dq=carchemish+battle+605&ei=0rNzSI6TIJXEigG_6_zpBw&client=firefox-a&sig=ACfU3U1Wzw_pgL4_ZsnOWUInugnu63dVpA] ==Records of the battle== The [[Nebuchadnezzar Chronicle]], now housed in the [[British Museum]], claims that Nebuchadnezzar "crossed the river to go against the Egyptian army which lay in Karchemiš. They fought with each other and the Egyptian army withdrew before him. He accomplished their defeat, decisively. As for the rest of the Egyptian army which had escaped from the defeat so quickly that no weapon had reached them, in the district of [[Hamath]] the Babylonian troops [[Battle of Hamath|overtook and defeated them]] so that not a single man escaped to his own country. At that time Nebuchadnezzar conquered the whole area of Hamath."[http://www.livius.org/cg-cm/chronicles/abc5/jerusalem.html Chronicle Concerning the Early Years of Nebuchadnezzar II. Retrieved July 18, 2010.] The battle is also mentioned and described in the [[Bible]], in the [[Book of Jeremiah]].The Bible, Jeremiah 46:3–12 The battle mentioned in 2 Chronicles 35:20-27 is not the same; the event referred to there is the [[Battle of Megiddo (609 BC)]], which occurred four years earlier, also near Carchemish (2 Chronicles 35:20). == Discrepancy == However, it is unclear historically if Pharaoh Necho II was for or against the king of Assyria, according to [[Josephus|Flavius Josephus]] in his record ''[[Antiquities of the Jews]]''{{Cite web|url=http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus:text:1999.01.0146:book=10:whiston+chapter=5:whiston+section=1|title=Flavius Josephus, Antiquities of the Jews, Book 10, Whiston chapter 5, Whiston section 1|website=www.perseus.tufts.edu|access-date=2017-12-07}} and various christian commentators, such as [[Matthew Henry]]{{Cite web|url=https://www.biblestudytools.com/commentaries/matthew-henry-complete/2-kings/23.html|title=2 Kings 23 Commentary - Matthew Henry Commentary on the Whole Bible (Complete)|website=Bible Study Tools|access-date=2017-12-07}} and John Peter Lange.{{Cite web|url=http://www.biblehub.com/commentaries/lange/2_kings/22.htm|title=2 Kings 22 Lange Commentary on the Holy Scriptures|website=www.biblehub.com|access-date=2017-12-07}} Such accounts render the battle as King Josiah either heroically trying to rescue the Assyrians from their enemies or attempting to avoid being surrounded by an enemy. ==Notes== {{reflist}} {{coord|36.8297|N|38.0150|E|source:wikidata|display=title}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Carchemish 605 Bc}} [[Category:605 BC]] [[Category:7th-century BC conflicts]] [[Category:Battles involving Babylonia]] [[Category:Battles involving ancient Egypt]] [[Category:Hebrew Bible battles]] [[Category:Battles involving Assyria]] [[Category:7th century BC]]

{{Infobox comics character| |image = |caption = The debut of Blue Ear, from ''Iron Man: Sound Effects'' #1 (December 2014).
Art by [[Karl Moline]]. |character_name = Blue Ear |real_name = Dr. Pedro Perez |publisher = [[Marvel Comics]] |debut = ''Iron Man: Sound Effects'' #1 (December 2014) |creators = Nelson Ribeiro |alliances = |aliases = |powers = Expert physicist
Sound manipulation |}} '''Blue Ear''' is a fictional [[superhero]] appearing in [[American comic book]]s published by [[Marvel Comics]].{{cite web|first= Julie |last= Hanson|url=http://www.unionleader.com/article/20120526/NEWS/705269948|title=Superheroes do wear blue ears, thanks to NH boy|work= The Union Leader|date=May 26, 2012|accessdate=May 27, 2012}} Marvel created the character in honor of Anthony Smith, a [[Deafness|hard-of-hearing]] 4-year-old comic book fan from [[Salem, New Hampshire|Salem]], [[New Hampshire]], USA.{{cite web| url= http://www.foxnews.com/us/2012/05/23/hearing-impaired-new-hampshire-boy-inspires-new-marvel-comics-super-hero/|title=Hearing-impaired New Hampshire boy inspires new Marvel Comics superhero| publisher= Fox News|date=May 23, 2012|accessdate=May 24, 2012}} Smith has no hearing in his right ear and minimal hearing in his left because he has Mosaic [[trisomy 22]].{{cite web|first= Michelle |last= Castillo|title=Marvel team creates deaf superhero called Blue Ear in honor of boy| url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-504763_162-57441863-10391704/marvel-team-creates-deaf-superhero-called-blue-ear-in-honor-of-boy/|publisher=CBS News|date=May 25, 2012|accessdate=May 27, 2012}} ==Publication history== Smith was given a [[hearing aid]] by his mother, Christina D'Allesandro, and was using it regularly until he became depressed and refused to wear it to school in 2012. According to Smith, "superheroes don't wear blue ears". D'Allesandro was alarmed by this and emailed Marvel Comics in [[New York City]] for assistance with the situation. Designer and assistant editor, Nelson Ribeiro, then created the original image of the Blue Ear{{cite web|url=http://fans.marvel.com/trades_department/blog/2012/05/24/the_blue_ear|title=The Blue Ear|publisher=''Marvel''|date=May 24, 2012|accessdate=June 26, 2013}} and sent it to the D'Allesandro family. Later, production artist [[Manny Mederos]] started working on a sketch of Blue Ear as a kid. Mederos told ''[[Huffington Post]]'' that during the creative process, Mederos had an idea: "Why not have the superhero be a young kid himself?"{{cite web|first= Ileana |last= Llorens| url= http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/05/22/marvel-comics-artists-create-blue-ear-hearing-impaired-boy_n_1537300.html|title=Anthony Smith, Hearing-Impaired Boy, Gets Custom Superhero, 'The Blue Ear,' From Marvel Comics |work= Huffington Post| date=May 22, 2012|accessdate=May 24, 2012}} Marvel Comics responded by sending D'Allesandro comics of [[Hawkeye (comics)|Hawkeye]] from the 1980s, when the superhero lost 80% of his hearing and had to wear hearing aids, along with a drawing of "The Blue Ear", a superhero based on Anthony, saying, "Thanks to my listening device I hear someone in trouble!"{{cite web|url=http://thedailywh.at/2012/05/24/heartwarming-tearjerker-of-the-day-58/|title=Heartwarming Tearjerker of the Day|publisher=The Daily What|date=May 24, 2012|accessdate=May 24, 2012|archive-url=https://archive.is/20120722155111/http://thedailywh.at/2012/05/24/heartwarming-tearjerker-of-the-day-58/#|archive-date=2012-07-22|dead-url=yes|df=}}{{cite web|first=Annmarie|last=Timmins|url=http://www.concordmonitor.com/article/330760/real-life-heroes?page=0,0|archive-url=https://archive.is/20120729182727/http://www.concordmonitor.com/article/330760/real-life-heroes?page=0,0|dead-url=yes|archive-date=July 29, 2012|title=Marvel Comics came through when a New Hampshire mom put out the call for help|work=[[Concord Monitor]]|date=May 20, 2012|accessdate=May 24, 2012}} D'Allesandro stated that Smith took the comic book pictures to his preschool, which pushed teachers to have a "superhero week".{{cite web|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/more-news/marvel-creates-new-superhero-for-hearing-impaired-new-hampshire-boy/story-e6frf7l6-1226365269279| title= Marvel creates new superhero for hearing-impaired New Hampshire boy| work=Herald Sun|date=May 24, 2012|accessdate=May 24, 2012}} Smith's grandfather, New Hampshire senator [[Lou D'Allesandro]], stated, "This is a feel good moment, it's a feel good story, and we've got to get the world to recognize that."{{cite web|first= Stacey |last= Leasca| url=http://www.globalpost.com/dispatches/globalpost-blogs/weird-wide-web/marvel-blue-ear-hearing-impaired-superhero|title=Blue Ear superhero created by Marvel for hearing impaired boy |publisher=Global Post|date=May 24, 2012|accessdate=May 24, 2012}} In March 2013, Smith attended an event at the Center for Hearing and Communication to debut a poster.{{cite web| first= JK |last= Parkin|url=http://robot6.comicbookresources.com/2013/03/iron-man-and-blue-ear-debut-poster-campaign-for-hearing-impaired-kids/|title= Iron Man and Blue Ear debut poster campaign for hearing-impaired kids|publisher=''Comic Book Resources''|work=Robot6|date= 2 March 2013| accessdate= March 10, 2013}} The Blue Ear character returned for his comic debut in a Team-up Marvel Custom Solutions Iron Man Issue, along with the titular Iron Man & new character named Sapheara, for another campaign for deaf kids. Under the costumes based on Nelson Ribeiro's design, Blue Ear this time was written under the name 'Dr. Pedro Perez', & was given an origin for his heroic identity.{{cite web| first= Tim |last= Stevens|url=http://marvel.com/news/comics/23586/iron_man_introduces_blue_ear/|title= IRON MAN INTRODUCES BLUE EAR|publisher=''Marvel''|date= 31 October 2014|accessdate= October 31, 2014}}{{cite web| url=http://read.marvel.com/#/labelbook/40645|title= ''Iron Man:Sound Effects'' #1|publisher=''Marvel''}} Blue Ear returns with Sapheara under a four-part, one-page 'Limited Comic Strip Series' called ''Blue Ear & Sapheara'' in celebration for Better Hearing & Speech Month.{{cite web| url=https://www.childrenshearing.org/sites/default/files/file/CHIBES1.pdf|title=''Blue Ear & Sapheara Part 1:Rooftop Rescue''|publisher=''Children's Hearing Institute, Marvel''}} ==See also== * [[Sign Gene]] ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Child characters in comics]] [[Category:Child superheroes]] [[Category:Comics based on real people]] [[Category:Comics characters introduced in 2012]] [[Category:Fictional deaf characters]] [[Category:Marvel Comics superheroes]] {{Marvel-hero-stub}}

{{Politics of Greece}} The Cabinet of [[Lucas Papademos]] succeeded the [[Cabinet of George Papandreou|cabinet]] of [[George Papandreou]], as an interim three-party coalition cabinet, leading a [[coalition government]] formed by the [[Panhellenic Socialist Movement]] (PASOK) party, [[New Democracy (Greece)|New Democracy]] party and [[Popular Orthodox Rally]] party,<ref>{{cite news|title=Lucas Papademos sworn in as Greece's prime minister|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/nov/11/lucas-papademos-greece-prime-minister|accessdate=12 November 2011|newspaper=Guardian|date=2011-11-11}}</ref> after Papandreou's decision to step down, and allow a [[national unity government|provisional coalition government]] to form with the task to take Greece out of a major political crisis caused by the country's [[Greek government debt crisis|debt crisis]].<ref name=BBC /><ref name=Guardian>{{citeweb|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/nov/10/lucas-papademos-greece-interim-coalition|title=Lucas Papademos to lead Greece's interim coalition government|date=10 November 2011|work=Guardian (UK)|accessdate=10 November 2011}}</ref> It was the first coalition cabinet in Greece since the 1989–1990 Ecumenical Cabinet of [[Xenophon Zolotas]].
The [[Prime Minister of Greece|Prime Minister]] Lucas Papademos and the [[Cabinet of Greece|Cabinet]] were formally sworn in on 11 November 2011.<ref>{{cite web|title=New Greek govt takes over, former banker at helm|url=http://hosted2.ap.org/APDEFAULT/3d281c11a96b4ad082fe88aa0db04305/Article_2011-11-11-EU-Greece-Financial-Crisis/id-98805fa6da654460a141ba38be2d63e7|publisher=Associated Press |accessdate=11 November 2011|date=11 November 2011}}</ref>
==Government formation process== {{wikinews|Greek PM survives confidence vote}} On November 6, Prime Minister George Papandreou met with opposition leaders to try to reach an agreement on the formation of an [[provisional government|interim government]], after a narrow confidence vote win in parliament.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-15604169 "Greek PM Papandreou faces unity challenge over bailout"] at bbc.co.uk</ref> A day earlier, the leader of the opposition New Democracy party [[Antonis Samaras]] had rejected the proposal and called for an immediate election. After Papandreou agreed to step aside, however, the two leaders announced their intention to form a [[national unity government]] that would allow the EU bailout to proceed and pave the way for [[next Greek legislative election|elections]] on 19 February 2012.<ref name="unity">{{Cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/nov/06/papandreou-greek-leaders-unity-deal |title=Papandreou out as Greek leaders agree unity government deal |last1=Kington |first1=Tom |last2=Smith |first2=Helena |publisher=''[[The Guardian]]'' |date=2011-11-06 |accessdate=2011-11-06}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://businesstoday.intoday.in/story/greek-pm-george-papandreou-resigns;-polls-set-for-february/1/19851.html |title=Greek PM George Papandreou resigns; polls set for February |publisher=Business Today |accessdate=7 November 2011}}</ref> The [[Communist Party of Greece|Communist Party]] and the [[Coalition of the Radical Left]] Party, refused Papandreou's invitation to join talks on a new unity government.<ref>{{cite web|title=Political opposition divided over unity government|url=http://www.ekathimerini.com/4dcgi/_w_articles_wsite1_1_07/11/2011_413717|publisher=e.kathemerini.com|accessdate=11 November 2011|date=7 November 2011}}</ref> After several days of intense negotiations, the two major parties along with the Popular Orthodox Rally agreed to form a [[grand coalition]] headed by former [[European Central Bank]] vice-president [[Lucas Papademos]].<ref name=BBC>{{cite web|title=Lucas Papademos named as new Greek prime minister|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-15671354|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=10 November 2011|date=10 November 2011}}</ref><ref name=Guardian />
On November 10, George Papandreou formally resigned as Prime Minister of Greece,<ref>{{cite web|title=George Papandreou resigns as Greece's prime minister|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/financialcrisis/8879647/George-Papandreou-resigns-as-Greeces-prime-minister.html|publisher=The Telegraph |accessdate=11 November 2011|date=9 November 2011}}</ref> and the new coalition cabinet and Prime Minister Lucas Papademos were formally sworn in on 11 November 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/11/11/us-greece-f-idUSTRE7AA2H720111111 |title=Papademos sworn in, heads Greek cabinet of stalwarts |publisher=Reuters |date= |accessdate=11 November 2011}}</ref>
The national unity government's main task was to allow the EU bailout to proceed and to pave the way for elections on 19 February 2012. Papademos, who was not an elected MP, has said his priority will be to keep Greece in the eurozone.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-15691697 |title=Greece swears in unity cabinet and PM Lucas Papademos |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=11 November 2011}}</ref>
==The Cabinet== In total, 48 people including the prime minister make up the government, seven more than its immediate predecessor. There are 12 new ministers in its ranks, of which nine have been sworn into government office for the first time, including the new premier. Broadly, most Cabinet members served in the previous government of George Papandreou. Nevertheless, the new coalition government also includes six members hailing from the main opposition New Democracy party.
On 10 February 2012, the Popular Orthodox Rally withdrew from the coalition government after refusing to support the latest austerity deal.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/business/2012/feb/10/debt-crisis-greece Greece on shaky ground as coalition party rejects troika loan deal], ''The Guardian'', 10 February 2012</ref> The party's only cabinet minister, [[Makis Voridis]], was expelled by [[Georgios Karatzaferis]] for supporting the package but retained his portfolio after consultations with the prime minister.<ref>{{cite news|title=«Ναι» στο Μνημόνιο από 199 βουλευτές και «όχι» από 74|url=http://www.tovima.gr/politics/article/?aid=443281|accessdate=7 March 2012|newspaper=[[To Vima]]|date=13 February 2012|location=Athens|language=Greek}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Χωρίς ανασχηματισμό η κυβέρνηση - Παραμένει ο Βορίδης|url=http://www.tovima.gr/politics/article/?aid=443589|accessdate=7 March 2012|newspaper=To Vima|date=14 February 2012|location=Athens|language=Greek}}</ref> A few days later, he joined New Democracy and surrendered his parliamentary seat to LAOS.<ref>{{cite news|title=Προσχώρησαν στη Ν.Δ. οι Μ. Βορίδης και Αδ. Γεωργιάδης|url=http://www.tovima.gr/politics/article/?aid=444113|accessdate=7 March 2012|newspaper=To Vima|date=17 February 2012|location=Athens|language=Greek}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Παρέδωσαν τις έδρες τους στο ΛΑΟΣ Μ. Βορίδης και Αδ. Γεωργιάδης|url=http://www.tovima.gr/politics/article/?aid=444209|accessdate=7 March 2012|newspaper=To Vima|date=17 February 2012|location=Athens|language=Greek}}</ref>
A minor cabinet reshuffle was announced in March 2012, after [[Christos Papoutsis]] resigned as [[Ministry of Citizen Protection (Greece)|Minister for Citizen Protection]] in order to pursue the PASOK leadership. He was replaced by [[Michalis Chrisochoidis]], who was succeeded as development minister by [[Anna Diamantopoulou]]. She was replaced in the education portfolio by [[Georgios Babiniotis]], a professor of [[linguistics]] and former rector of the [[University of Athens]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Υπουργός Παιδείας ο Γ. {{Globalize/US|date=December 2017}} '''Central bank liquidity swap''' is a type of [[currency swap]] used by a country's central bank to provide liquidity of its currency to another country's central bank.<ref>{{cite web|title=Central banks to restore currency swaps|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/2a88cdda-5bdb-11df-85a3-00144feab49a.html#axzz1JqYrs5r2|date=May 10, 2010 |work=ft.com|author=James Politi }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/04/18/china-newzealand-swaps-idUSL3E7FI0LH20110418|title=China, New Zealand sign 25 bln yuan currency swap deal |author=Zhou Xin |author2=Kevin Yao|date=Apr 18, 2011|work=Reuters}}</ref>
In the United States the Federal Reserve operates swap lines under the authority of Section 14 of the [[Federal Reserve Act]] and in compliance with authorizations, policies, and procedures established by the FOMC.
==History== On December 12, 2007, the [[Federal Open Market Committee]] (FOMC) announced that it had authorized temporary reciprocal currency arrangements ('''central bank liquidity swap''' lines) with the [[European Central Bank]] and the [[Swiss National Bank]] to help provide liquidity in U.S. dollars to overseas markets.<ref name="Fed CBLS">{{cite web | title = Central bank liquidity swaps | work =Credit and Liquidity Programs and the Balance Sheet | publisher =Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System | date =2009-04-02 | url =http://www.federalreserve.gov/monetarypolicy/bst_liquidityswaps.htm | accessdate = 2009-04-17}}</ref> Subsequently, the FOMC authorized liquidity swap lines with additional central banks. The swap lines are designed to improve liquidity conditions in U.S. and foreign financial markets by providing foreign [[central bank]]s with the capacity to deliver U.S. dollar funding to institutions in their jurisdictions during times of market stress.<ref name="Fed FAQ">{{cite web | title = Frequently asked questions: central bank liquidity swaps | work =Credit and Liquidity Programs and the Balance Sheet | publisher =Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System | date =2009-04-02 | url =http://www.federalreserve.gov/monetarypolicy/bst_swapfaqs.htm | accessdate = 2009-04-17}}</ref>
{{As of|2009|4}}, swap lines were authorized with the following institutions: the [[Reserve Bank of Australia]], the [[Banco Central do Brasil]], the [[Bank of Canada]], [[Danmarks Nationalbank]], the [[Bank of England]], the [[European Central Bank]], the [[Bank of Japan]], the [[Bank of Korea]], the [[Banco de Mexico]], the [[Reserve Bank of New Zealand]], [[Norges Bank]], the [[Monetary Authority of Singapore]], [[Sveriges Riksbank]], and the Swiss National Bank. The FOMC authorized these liquidity swap lines through October 30, 2009.
By November 2011, swap agreements were extended until February 2013, at lower interest rates.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/money/2011/11/30/142945987/the-central-banks-are-doing-what|accessdate=2012-01-02|date=2011-11-30|title=The Central Banks Are Doing What?}}</ref>
==Description== These swaps involve two transactions. When a foreign central bank draws on its swap line with the Federal Reserve, the foreign central bank sells a specified amount of its currency to the Federal Reserve in exchange for dollars at the prevailing market exchange rate. The Federal Reserve holds the foreign currency in an account at the foreign central bank. The dollars that the Federal Reserve provides are deposited in an account that the foreign central bank maintains at the [[Federal Reserve Bank of New York]]. At the same time, the Federal Reserve and the foreign central bank enter into a binding agreement for a second transaction that obligates the foreign central bank to buy back its currency on a specified future date at the same exchange rate. The second transaction unwinds the first. At the conclusion of the second transaction, the foreign central bank pays interest, at a market-based rate, to the Federal Reserve.
When the foreign central bank lends the dollars it obtained by drawing on its swap line to institutions in its jurisdiction, the dollars are transferred from the foreign central bank's account at the Federal Reserve to the account of the bank that the borrowing institution uses to clear its dollar transactions. The foreign central bank remains obligated to return the dollars to the Federal Reserve under the terms of the agreement, and the Federal Reserve is not a counterparty to the loan extended by the foreign central bank. The foreign central bank bears the credit risk associated with the loans it makes to institutions in its jurisdiction.
==Revenue and cost impacts== The foreign currency that the Federal Reserve acquires is an asset on the Federal Reserve's balance sheet. In tables 1, 9, and 10 of the H.4.1 statistical release, the dollar value of amounts that the foreign central banks have drawn but not yet repaid is reported in the line "Central bank liquidity swaps."<ref name="Fed h41">{{cite web | title = Factors Affecting Reserve Balances | work =Federal Reserve Statistical Release | publisher =Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System | date =2009-04-02 | url =http://www.federalreserve.gov/releases/h41/ | accessdate = 2009-04-17}}</ref> Because the swap will be unwound at the same exchange rate that was used in the initial draw, the dollar value of the asset is not affected by changes in the market exchange rate. The dollar funds deposited in the accounts that foreign central banks maintain at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York are a Federal Reserve liability. In principle, draws would initially appear in tables 1, 9, and 10 in the line "foreign and official" deposits. However, the foreign central banks generally lend the dollars shortly after drawing on the swap line. At that point, the funds shift to the line "deposits of depository institutions."
When a foreign central bank draws on its swap line to fund its dollar tender operations, it pays interest to the Federal Reserve in an amount equal to the interest the foreign central bank earns on its tender operations. The Federal Reserve holds the foreign currency that it acquires in the swap transaction at the foreign central bank (rather than lending it or investing it in private markets) and does not pay interest. The structure of the arrangement serves to avoid domestic currency reserve management difficulties for foreign central banks that could arise if the Federal Reserve actively invested the foreign currency holdings in the marketplace.<ref name="Fed FAQ"/>
The Federal Reserve Board issues a weekly release that includes information on the aggregate value of swap drawings outstanding. With the onset of the [[Global financial crisis of 2008–2009]] and the collapse of [[Lehman Brothers]] on September 15, 2008, the balance grew rapidly. {{As of|2009|April}} the balance was $293,533 million.<ref name="Fed h41"/> Central bank liquidity swaps have maturities ranging from overnight to three months. Table 2 of the H.4.1 statistical release reports the remaining maturity of outstanding central bank liquidity swaps.<ref name="Fed h41"/>

{{short description|non-profit professional theater company in Chicago}} [[File:Navy Pier Chicago.JPG|thumb|275px|The Theater is located on Navy Pier in the building to the right.]] '''Chicago Shakespeare Theater''' ('''CST''') is a non-profit, professional theater company located at [[Navy Pier]] in [[Chicago, Illinois]]. Its more than six hundred annual performances performed 48 weeks of the year include its critically acclaimed Shakespeare series, its World's Stage touring productions, and youth and family oriented programming concentrated in the summer. The theater had garnered 77 [[Joseph Jefferson awards]] and three [[Laurence Olivier Awards]]. In 2008, it was the winner of the [[Regional Theatre Tony Award]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://navypier.com/chicago-shakespeare-theater/|title=Chicago Shakespeare Theater - Navy Pier|publisher=}}</ref>
==Background== The company's present artistic director [[Barbara Gaines (director)|Barbara Gaines]] founded the theater in 1986, when it began performances on the roof of the Red Lion Pub in the city's [[Lincoln Park, Chicago|Lincoln Park neighborhood]]. In 1999, the company received permission to build its permanent home: a two-venue facility at [[Navy Pier]].
Productions at the theater include works from the [[Shakespeare's plays|Shakespearean canon]] as well as other plays and musicals. In addition to its own original productions, the Chicago Shakespare Theater also hosts touring productions from other theater companies.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.chicagoshakes.com/about_us/about|title=Chicago Shakespeare Theater About Us|publisher=}}</ref>
Chicago Shakespeare Theater is part of Theatre Communications Group (TCG), the [[Shakespeare Theatre Association of America]] (STAA) and National Alliance for Musical Theatre (NAMT) and the National Council of Teachers of English (NCTE).
==History== Chicago Shakespeare Theater was founded as the Chicago Shakespeare Workshop by current Artistic Director Barbara Gaines in 1986, a name which was changed a year later to the Chicago Shakespeare Repertory and finally in 1999 to Chicago Shakespeare Theater. It performed its first twelve seasons in residency at the Ruth Page Theater, where it performed titles ranging from better-known Shakespeare plays such as ''Hamlet'' and ''King Lear'' as well as lesser-known titles such as ''Troilus and Cressida'' and ''Timon of Athens''. Although the theater was critically lauded for its innovative approach to classic works, it was limited by the age and spatial restrictions of the Ruth Page Theater and began looking for a new performance space in the late 1990s.
In 1997, CST announced its plans to move from the Ruth Page to a new facility located at [[Navy Pier]], a place better known for its family attractions and in fact the most popular tourist attraction in the [[Midwest]]. The move was accompanied by a public relations blitz, which even involved Mayor [[Richard M. Daley]] naming April 23, 1997 Shakespeare Repertory Day. The company began a large-scale capital campaign to finance the move, and opened its 1999-2000 season in its new, state-of-the-art facility. Since then, CST has grown from the third-largest theater company in [[Chicago, Illinois|Chicago]] to the third-largest in the entire [[Midwest]], at a rate 400% faster than the industry growth trend.
==Facilities== Chicago Shakespeare Theater has, since October 1999, been in residence in a new, seven-story, {{convert|75000|m2|sqft|sing=on}} facility on Chicago's [[Navy Pier]], which houses its box office, administrative offices, and performance venues. The first performance at this facility was [[Eric Idle]] reading from his [[novel]], ''[[The Road to Mars]]''.
The 510-seat Courtyard Theater, which is the primary production venue for CST, features state-of-the-art technology and acoustics together with a versatile thrust stage and deep proscenium, that create a flexible performance space. A second theater, the 200-seat black box "Upstairs" space, is devoted to smaller but still-popular productions such as [[The Second City]]'s smash hit, ''Romeo and Juliet Musical: The People Vs. Friar Laurence, The Man Who Killed Romeo and Juliet''.
==Educational outreach== Chicago Shakespeare Theater's "Team Shakespeare" program is the largest arts-in-education program in the state of Illinois. The program reaches 40,000 students annually through student matinée performances of its full-length production, an abridged Shakespeare production that each year is staged both at its home on Navy Pier and on tour to schools across the region, and discussions. Its extensive work with approximately 1,000 educators annually includes free teacher workshops and web-based resources.
==Awards == * 2016 production of ''The Tempest'' received the 2016 [[Jeff Award|Joseph Jefferson Award]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/entertainment/theater/news/ct-2016-equity-jeff-awards-winners-20161014-story.html|title='Dreamgirls' and 'Tempest' win at 2016 Equity Jeff Awards|first=Chris|last=Jones|publisher=Chicago Tribune}}</ref>

{{EngvarA|date=March 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2014}} [[File:Child-soldier-afrika.jpg|thumb|250px|''Child Soldier in the Ivory Coast'' [[Gilbert G. Groud]], 2007]]{{Child soldiers}} {{History of war}} {{Slavery}}'''Children in the military''' are children (defined by the [[Convention on the Rights of the Child]] as persons under the age of 18) who are associated with military organisations, such as state [[Military|armed forces]] and [[Violent non-state actor|non-state armed groups]].<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=https://www.unicef.org/emerg/files/ParisPrinciples310107English.pdf|title=The Paris Principles: Principles and guidelines on children associated with armed forces or armed groups|last=UNICEF|first=|date=2007|website=|access-date=2018-01-24}}</ref> Throughout history and in many cultures, children have been involved in military campaigns.<ref name="Wessells">{{cite journal|last1=Wessels|first1=Michael|title=Child Soldiers|journal=Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists|date=1997|volume=53|issue=4|page=32}}</ref> For example, thousands of children participated on all sides of the First World War and the Second World War.<ref name=":41">{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/guides/zcvdhyc |title=How did Britain let 250000 underage soldiers fight in WW1? |work=BBC News}}</ref><ref name=":43">[[Norman Davies]], [https://books.google.com/books?id=Jzxt9FFBDPwC&pg=PA603 ''Rising '44: The Battle for Warsaw,''] Pan Books 2004 p.603</ref><ref name="Rosen2005">{{cite book |author=David M. Rosen |title=Armies of the Young: Child Soldiers in War and Terrorism |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zQYQ0tho6mAC&pg=PA55 |date=January 2005 |publisher=Rutgers University Press |isbn=978-0-8135-3568-5 |pages=54–55 |quote=The participation of Jewish children and youth in warfare was driven by a combination of necessity, honor, and moral duty.}}</ref><ref name="Kucherenko2011">{{cite book |last=Kucherenko |first=Olga |title=Little Soldiers: How Soviet Children Went to War, 1941–1945 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=92R8Pmr6xoAC&pg=PR3-IA96 |date=13 January 2011 |publisher=OUP Oxford |isbn=978-0-19-161099-8 |page=3}}</ref> Children may be trained and used for combat, assigned to support roles such as porters or messengers, or used for tactical advantage as [[human shield]]s or for political advantage in [[propaganda]].<ref name=":2" /><ref name="Children at war">{{Cite news|url=http://www.historyextra.com/podcast/children-war|title=Children at war|work=History Extra|access-date=2017-12-07|language=en}}</ref>
Children are easy targets for [[military recruitment]] due to their greater susceptibility to influence compared to adults.<ref name="ReferenceB" /><ref name=":32">{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/427757599|title=On killing : the psychological cost of learning to kill in war and society|last=Dave.|first=Grossman,|date=2009|publisher=Little, Brown and Co|isbn=9780316040938|edition=Rev.|location=New York|oclc=427757599}}</ref><ref name="Wessells" /><ref name=":22">{{Cite book|title=Military life: The psychology of serving in peace and combat|chapter=Joining the ranks: The role of indoctrination in transforming civilians to service members|volume=volume 2: Operational stress|author1-last=McGurk|author1-first=Dennis|author2-last=Cotting|author2-first=Dave I.|author3-last=Britt|author3-first=Thomas W.|author4-last=Adler|author4-first=Amy B.|publisher=Praeger Security International|editor1-last=Adler|editor1-first=Amy B.|editor2-last=Castro|editor2-first=Carl Andrew|editor3-last=Britt|editor3-first=Thomas W.|year=2006|isbn=978-0275983024|location=Westport|pages=13–31}}</ref> Some are recruited by force while others choose to join up, often to escape poverty or because they expect military life to offer a [[rite of passage]] to maturity.<ref name="Wessells" /><ref name=":12" /><ref name=":103" /><ref name=":82">{{Cite web|url=https://www.child-soldiers.org/Handlers/Download.ashx?IDMF=26c0549d-aa35-4f1a-8e34-5956f8e2ec51|title=Child Soldiers Global Report 2008|last=Coalition to Stop the Use of Child Soldiers|first=|date=2008|website=|access-date=2018-05-16}}</ref><ref name=":14" />
Child recruits who survive armed conflict frequently suffer psychiatric illness, poor literacy and numeracy, and behavioural problems such as heightened aggression, leading to a high risk of poverty and unemployment in adulthood.<ref name=":15" /> Research in the UK and US has also found that the enlistment of adolescent children, even when they are not sent to war, is accompanied by a higher risk of attempted suicide,<ref name=":30" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/694167/20180327_Suicide_and_open_verdict_deaths_in_the_UK_Regular_Armed_Forces_1984-2017_Tables_and_Figures-O.xls|title=UK armed forces suicide and open verdict deaths: 1984-2017|last=UK, Ministry of Defence|first=|date=2017|website=|access-date=2018-05-24}}</ref> stress-related mental disorders,<ref name=":28" /><ref name=":29" /> alcohol misuse,<ref name=":31" /><ref name=":33" /> and violent behaviour.<ref name=":34" /><ref name=":35" /><ref name=":36" />
A number of treaties have sought to curb the participation of children in armed conflicts. According to [[Child Soldiers International]] these agreements have helped to reduce child recruitment,<ref name=":5" /> but the practice remains widespread and children continue to participate in hostilities around the world.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=https://www.child-soldiers.org/Handlers/Download.ashx?IDMF=da92581e-7130-40e6-bf3a-a86b944f17dd|title=Louder than words: An agenda for action to end state use of child soldiers|last=Child Soldiers International|first=|date=2012|website=|access-date=19 January 2018}}</ref><ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=https://www.child-soldiers.org/Handlers/Download.ashx?IDMF=38e90749-3a76-4441-82dc-bd49f1217599|title=A law unto themselves? Confronting the recruitment of children by armed groups|last=Child Soldiers International|first=|date=2016|website=|access-date=19 January 2018}}</ref> Some economically powerful nations continue to rely on military recruits aged 16 or 17, and the use of younger children in armed conflict has increased in recent years as militant [[Islamism|Islamist]] movements and the groups fighting them recruited children in large numbers.<ref name=":17" />
{{TOC limit|limit=3}}
==History== {{Main|History of children in the military}} History is filled with children who have been trained and used for combat, assigned to support roles such as porters or messengers, used as sex slaves, or recruited for tactical advantage as [[human shield]]s or for political advantage in [[propaganda]].<ref name=":2" /><ref name="Children at war"/><ref name=":48">{{cite web|url=http://womennewsnetwork.net/2009/01/13/ugandagirlsoldier809/|title=Girl Soldiers – The cost of survival in Northern Uganda, Women News Network – WNN|date=13 January 2009|publisher=Womennewsnetwork.net|accessdate=12 May 2012}}</ref> In 1814, for example, Napoleon conscripted many teenagers for his armies.<ref>Michael Leggiere, The Fall of Napoleon: The Allied Invasion of France 1813–1814, pg.99–100</ref> Thousands of children participated on all sides of the First World War and the Second World War.<ref name=":41">{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/guides/zcvdhyc |title=How did Britain let 250000 underage soldiers fight in WW1? |work=BBC News}}</ref><ref name=":43">[[Norman Davies]], [https://books.google.com/books?id=Jzxt9FFBDPwC&pg=PA603 ''Rising '44: The Battle for Warsaw,''] Pan Books 2004 p.603</ref><ref name="Rosen2005">{{cite book |author=David M. Rosen |title=Armies of the Young: Child Soldiers in War and Terrorism |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zQYQ0tho6mAC&pg=PA55 |date=January 2005 |publisher=Rutgers University Press |isbn=978-0-8135-3568-5 |pages=54–55 |quote=The participation of Jewish children and youth in warfare was driven by a combination of necessity, honor, and moral duty.}}</ref><ref name="Kucherenko2011">{{cite book |last=Kucherenko |first=Olga |title=Little Soldiers: How Soviet Children Went to War, 1941–1945 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=92R8Pmr6xoAC&pg=PR3-IA96 |date=13 January 2011 |publisher=OUP Oxford |isbn=978-0-19-161099-8 |page=3}}</ref> Children continued to be used throughout the 20th and early 21st century on every continent, with concentrations in parts of Africa, Latin America, and the Middle East.<ref name="CSGR2004-292" /> Only since the turn of the millennium have international efforts begun to limit and reduce the military use of children.<ref name=":14" /><ref name=":02" />
==Current situation==
=== State armed forces === Since the adoption in 2000 of the [[Optional Protocol on the Involvement of Children in Armed Conflict|Optional Protocol on the involvement of children in armed conflict]] (OPAC) the global trend has been towards restricting armed forces recruitment to adults aged 18 or over, known as the ''Straight-18'' standard.<ref name=":5" /><ref name=":7">{{Cite news|url=https://www.child-soldiers.org/international-laws-and-child-rights|title=International laws and child rights|last=Child Soldiers International|first=|date=2017|work=|access-date=2018-01-25|language=en}}</ref> Most states with armed forces have opted in to OPAC, which also prohibits states that still recruit children from using them in armed conflict.<ref name=":7" />
Nonetheless, Child Soldiers International reported in 2018 that children under the age of 18 were still being recruited and trained for military purposes in 46 countries;<ref name=":39">{{Cite web|url=http://childsoldiersworldindex.org/|title=Child Soldiers World Index|last=Child Soldiers International|first=|date=2018|website=childsoldiersworldindex.org|language=en|access-date=2018-03-29}}</ref> of these, most recruit from age 17, fewer than 20 recruit from age 16, and an unknown, smaller number, recruit younger children.<ref name=":5">{{Cite news|url=https://www.child-soldiers.org/where-are-there-child-soldiers|title=Where are child soldiers?|last=Child Soldiers International|first=|date=2017|work=|access-date=2018-01-25|language=en}}</ref><ref name=":3" /><ref name=":6">{{Cite web|url=http://www.un.org/ga/search/view_doc.asp?symbol=S/2017/821&Lang=E&Area=UNDOC|title=Report of the Secretary-General: Children and armed conflict, 2017|last=United Nations Secretary-General|first=|date=2017|website=www.un.org|page=41|access-date=2018-01-24}}</ref> States that still rely on children to staff their armed forces include the world's three most populous countries (China, India, and the United States) and the most economically powerful (all G7 countries apart from Italy and Japan).<ref name=":3" /> The United Nations [[Committee on the Rights of the Child]] and others have called for an end to the recruitment of children by state armed forces, arguing that [[Recruit training|military training]], the military environment, and a binding contract of service are not compatible with children's rights and jeopardise healthy development during adolescence.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://tbinternet.ohchr.org/_layouts/treatybodyexternal/Download.aspx?symbolno=CRC/C/GC/20&Lang=en|title=General comment No. 20 (2016) on the implementation of the rights of the child during adolescence|last=Committee on the Rights of the Child|first=|date=2016|website=tbinternet.ohchr.org|language=en-us|access-date=2018-01-25}}</ref><ref name=":3" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://downloads.unicef.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/UnicefChildSoldiersbriefing_UKweb.pdf?_ga=2.190210859.1420289747.1516916352-952164330.1516916352|title=Ending the recruitment and use of children in armed conflict|last=UNICEF|first=|date=2017|website=|access-date=2018-01-25}}</ref><ref name=":19">{{Cite web|url=https://childrenandarmedconflict.un.org/children-not-soldiers/|title=Children, Not Soldiers {{!}} United Nations Office of the Special Representative of the Secretary-General for Children and Armed Conflict|website=childrenandarmedconflict.un.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-01-25}}</ref>
=== Non-state armed groups === These include [[Violent non-state actor|non-state armed]] [[Paramilitary|paramilitary organisations]], using children such as [[militia]]s, [[insurgent]]s, [[terrorist organization]]s, [[Guerrilla warfare|guerrilla movements]], ideologically or religiously-driven groups, armed [[liberation movement]]s, and other types of quasi-military organisation. In 2017 the United Nations identified 14 countries where children were widely used by such groups: Afghanistan, Colombia, [[Child soldiers in the Central African Republic|Central African Republic]], [[Child soldiers in the Democratic Republic of the Congo|Democratic Republic of the Congo]], Iraq, Mali, Myanmar, Nigeria, Philippines, [[Child soldiers in Somalia|Somalia]], South Sudan, Sudan, Syria, and Yemen.<ref name=":17" />
Not all armed groups use children and approximately 60 have entered agreements to reduce or end the practice since 1999.<ref name=":4" /> For example, by 2017, the [[Moro Islamic Liberation Front]] (MILF) in the Philippines had released nearly 2,000 children from its ranks,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.unicef.org/philippines/media_27217.html|title=UN Officials congratulate MILF for completion of disengagement of children from its ranks|last=UNICEF|first=|date=4 December 2017|website=www.unicef.org|access-date=2018-01-25}}</ref> and in 2016, the [[Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia|FARC-EP]] guerrilla movement in Colombia agreed to stop recruiting children.<ref name=":17" /> Other countries have seen the reverse trend, particularly Afghanistan, Iraq, Nigeria and Syria, where [[Islamism|Islamist]] militants and groups opposing them have intensified their recruitment, training, and use of children.<ref name=":17">{{Cite web|url=http://www.un.org/ga/search/view_doc.asp?symbol=S/2017/821&Lang=E&Area=UNDOC|title=Report of the Secretary-General: Children and armed conflict, 2017|last=United Nations Secretary-General|first=|date=2017|website=www.un.org|access-date=2018-01-24}}</ref>
=== Global estimate === In 2003 [[P. W. Singer]] of the [[Brookings Institution]] estimated that child soldiers participate in about three-quarters of ongoing conflicts.<ref name="saddam">{{cite web|url=http://www.brookings.edu/papers/2003/0114iraq_singer.aspx|title=Facing Saddam's Child Soldiers|author=[[P. W. Singer]]|date=14 January 2003|publisher=[[Brookings Institution]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100212100221/http://www.brookings.edu/papers/2003/0114iraq_singer.aspx|archivedate=12 February 2010|deadurl=yes|accessdate=3 August 2009|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In the same year the [[UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs]] (UNOCHA) estimated that most of these children were aged over 15, although some were younger.<ref name="irin">{{cite web|url=http://www.irinnews.org/report/66280/africa-too-small-to-be-fighting-in-anyone-s-war|title=AFRICA: Too small to be fighting in anyone's war|last=|first=|date=December 2003|website=|publisher=UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130325052712/http://www.irinnews.org/Report/66280/AFRICA-Too-small-to-be-fighting-in-anyone-s-war|archive-date=2013-03-25|dead-url=yes|accessdate=3 August 2009}}</ref>
Today, due to the widespread military use of children in areas where armed conflict and insecurity prevent access by UN officials and other third parties, it is difficult to estimate how many children are affected.<ref name=":8">{{Cite news|url=https://www.child-soldiers.org/FAQs/how-many-children-are-used-for-military-purposes-worldwide|title=How many children are used for military purposes worldwide?|last=Child Soldiers International|first=|date=2017|work=|access-date=2018-01-25|language=en}}</ref> In 2017 Child Soldiers International estimated that several tens of thousands of children, possibly more than 100,000, were in state- and non-state military organisations around the world,<ref name=":8" /> and in 2018 the organisation reported that children were being used to participate in at least 18 armed conflicts.<ref name=":39" />
==Rationale for the use of children==
Despite children's physical and psychological underdevelopment relative to adults, there are many reasons why state- and non-state military organisations seek them out. Cited examples include: * Peter Singer has suggested that the global proliferation of light automatic weapons, which children can easily handle, has made the use of children as direct combatants more viable.<ref>{{cite book|title=Children at War|last1=Singer|first1=Peter|date=2005|publisher=Pantheon Books|location=New York}}</ref> * [[Roméo Dallaire]] has pointed to the role of overpopulation in making children a cheap and accessible resource for military organisations.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Dallaire|first1=Roméo|title=They Fight Like Soldiers, They Die Like Children: The Global Quest to Eradicate the Use of Child Soldiers|date=2011|publisher=Walker and Company|location=New York}}</ref> * Roger Rosenblatt has suggested that children are more willing than adults to fight for non-monetary incentives such as honour, prestige, revenge and duty.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Rosenblatt|first1=Roger|title=Children of War|journal=American Educator 8|date=1984|volume=1|pages=37–41}}</ref> * Several commentators, including Bernd Beber, Christopher Blattman, Dave Grossman, Michael Wessels, and McGurk and colleagues, have argued that since children are more obedient and malleable than adults, they are easier to control, deceive and indoctrinate.<ref name="ReferenceB">{{cite journal|last1=Beber, Blattman|first1=Bernd, Christopher|title=The Logic of Child Soldiering and Coercion|journal=International Organization|date=2013|volume=67|issue=1|pages=65–104|doi=10.1017/s0020818312000409}}</ref><ref name=":32" /><ref name="Wessells" /><ref name=":22" /> * David Gee and Rachel Taylor have found that in the UK, the army finds it easier to attract child recruits starting from age 16 than adults from age 18.<ref name=":103">{{Cite journal|last=Gee|first=David|last2=Taylor|first2=Rachel|date=2016-11-01|title=Is it Counterproductive to Enlist Minors into the Army?|url=https://doi.org/10.1080/03071847.2016.1265837|journal=The RUSI Journal|volume=161|issue=6|pages=36–48|doi=10.1080/03071847.2016.1265837|issn=0307-1847}}</ref> * Some leaders of armed groups have claimed that children, despite their underdevelopment, bring their own qualities as combatants to a fighting unit, often being remarkably fearless, agile and hardy.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Beber|first=Bernd|last2=Blattman|first2=Christopher|date=2013|title=The Logic of Child Soldiering and Coercion|url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/international-organization/article/logic-of-child-soldiering-and-coercion/EB8CC2FE13CC49C2846EEDE4FFD432FE|journal=International Organization|language=en|volume=67|issue=1|pages=65–104|doi=10.1017/s0020818312000409|issn=0020-8183|via=}}</ref> While some children are forcibly recruited, deceived, or bribed into joining military organisations, others join of their own volition.<ref name=":12">{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/53830868|title=Young soldiers : why they choose to fight|last=Brett|first=R|last2=Specht|first2=I|date=|publisher=Lynne Rienner Publishers|others=|year=2004|isbn=9781588262615|location=Boulder, Colo.|pages=|oclc=53830868}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.child-soldiers.org/shop/des-milliers-de-vies-rparer|title=Des Milliers de vies à réparer|last=Child Soldiers International|first=|date=2016|website=|language=fr|access-date=2018-01-29}}</ref><ref name="Wessells" /> There are many reasons for this. In a 2004 study of children in military organisations around the world, Rachel Brett and Irma Specht pointed to a complex of factors that incentivise enlisting, particularly: * Background poverty including a lack of civilian education or employment opportunities * The cultural normalisation of war * Seeking new friends * Revenge (for example, after seeing friends and relatives killed) * Expectations that a "warrior" role provides a [[rite of passage]] to maturity<ref name=":12" />
The following testimony from a child recruited by the Cambodian armed forces in the 1990s is typical of many children's motivations for joining up:
<blockquote>I joined because my parents lacked food and I had no school... I was worried about mines but what can we do—it's an order [to go to the [[front line]]]. Once somebody stepped on a mine in front of me—he was wounded and died... I was with the radio at the time, about 60 metres away. I was sitting in my hammock and saw him die... I see young children in every unit... I'm sure I'll be a soldier for at least a couple of more years. If I stop being a soldier I won't have a job to do because I don't have any skills. I don't know what I'll do...<ref name=":410">{{Cite web|url=https://www.child-soldiers.org/Handlers/Download.ashx?IDMF=adc88bff-1916-4317-b184-d9079e7b0bb8|title=Global Report on Child Soldiers|last=Coalition to Stop the Use of Child Soldiers|first=|date=2001|website=child-soldiers.org|access-date=2018-05-16}}</ref></blockquote>
== Impact on children ==
{{Further|Impact of war on children}}{{See also|Recruit training}}
The scale of the impact on children was first acknowledged by the international community in a major report commissioned by the [[United Nations General Assembly|UN General Assembly]], ''Impact of Armed Conflict on Children'' (1996), which was produced by the human rights expert [[Graça Machel]].<ref name=":14" /> The report was particularly concerned with the use of younger children, presenting evidence that many thousands of children were being killed, maimed, and [[Mental disorder|psychiatrically injured]] around the world every year.<ref name=":14" />
Since the ''Machel Report'' further research has shown that child recruits who survive armed conflict face a markedly elevated risk of debilitating psychiatric illness, poor literacy and numeracy, and behavioural problems.<ref name=":15">{{Cite web|url=https://www.scribd.com/document/328940882/Child-Soldiering-Impact-on-Childhood-Development-and-Learning-Capacity|title=Child soldiering: Impact on childhood development and learning capacity|last=Boothby, N et al.|first=|date=2010|website=|access-date=2018-01-30}}</ref> Research in Palestine and Uganda, for example, has found that more than half of former child soldiers showed symptoms of [[Posttraumatic stress disorder|post-traumatic stress disorder]] and nearly nine in ten in Uganda screened positive for [[Depression (mood)|depressed mood]].<ref name=":15" /> Researchers in Palestine also found that children exposed to high levels of violence in armed conflict were substantially more likely than other children to exhibit [[aggression]] and [[anti-social behaviour]].<ref name=":15" /> The combined impact of these effects typically includes a high risk of poverty and lasting unemployment in adulthood.<ref name=":15" />
Further harm is caused when child recruits are detained by armed forces and groups, according to [[Human Rights Watch]].<ref name=":50">{{Cite web|url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2016/07/28/children-detained-war-zones|title=Children Detained in War Zones|date=2016-07-28|access-date=2016-08-21}}</ref> Children are often detained without sufficient food, medical care, or under other inhumane conditions, and some experience physical and sexual torture.<ref name=":50" /> Some are captured with their families, or detained due to the activity of one of their family members. Lawyers and relatives are frequently banned from any court hearing.<ref name=":50" />
Other research has found that the enlistment of children, including older children, has a detrimental impact even when they are not used in armed conflict until they reach adulthood. Military academics in the US have characterised military training (at all ages) as "intense indoctrination" in conditions of sustained stress, the primary purpose of which is to establish the unconditional and immediate obedience of recruits.<ref name=":22" /> The academic literature has found that adolescents are more vulnerable than adults to a high-stress environment, such as that of [[Recruit training|initial military training]], particularly those from a background of childhood adversity.<ref name=":47">{{Cite web|url=http://data.parliament.uk/writtenevidence/committeeevidence.svc/evidencedocument/defence-committee/armed-forces-and-veterans-mental-health/written/79963.html|title=House of Commons Defence Committee Inquiry into Armed Forces and Veterans Mental Health: Written Evidence Submitted by Medact|last=Medact|first=|date=2018|website=|access-date=2018-03-24}}{{dead link|date=September 2018|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> Enlistment, even before recruits are sent to war, is accompanied by a higher risk of attempted suicide in the US,<ref name=":30">{{Cite journal|last=Ursano|first=Robert J.|last2=Kessler|first2=Ronald C.|last3=Stein|first3=Murray B.|last4=Naifeh|first4=James A.|last5=Aliaga|first5=Pablo A.|last6=Fullerton|first6=Carol S.|last7=Wynn|first7=Gary H.|last8=Vegella|first8=Patti L.|last9=Ng|first9=Tsz Hin Hinz|date=2016-07-01|title=Risk Factors, Methods, and Timing of Suicide Attempts Among US Army Soldiers|url=http://archpsyc.jamanetwork.com/article.aspx?doi=10.1001/jamapsychiatry.2016.0600|journal=JAMA Psychiatry|language=en|volume=73|issue=7|doi=10.1001/jamapsychiatry.2016.0600|issn=2168-622X|page=741}}</ref> higher risk of mental disorders in the US and the UK,<ref name=":28">{{Cite journal|last=Goodwin|first=L.|last2=Wessely|first2=S.|last3=Hotopf|first3=M.|last4=Jones|first4=M.|last5=Greenberg|first5=N.|last6=Rona|first6=R. J.|last7=Hull|first7=L.|last8=Fear|first8=N. T.|date=2015|title=Are common mental disorders more prevalent in the UK serving military compared to the general working population?|url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/psychological-medicine/article/are-common-mental-disorders-more-prevalent-in-the-uk-serving-military-compared-to-the-general-working-population/B93009A3084218BCDB1D7AD3AAA6B7BF|journal=Psychological Medicine|language=en|volume=45|issue=9|pages=1881–1891|doi=10.1017/s0033291714002980|issn=0033-2917|via=}}</ref><ref name=":29">{{Cite journal|last=Martin|first=Pamela Davis|last2=Williamson|first2=Donald A.|last3=Alfonso|first3=Anthony J.|last4=Ryan|first4=Donna H.|date=February 2006|title=Psychological adjustment during Army basic training|journal=Military Medicine|volume=171|issue=2|pages=157–160|issn=0026-4075|pmid=16578988|doi=10.7205/milmed.171.2.157}}</ref> higher risk of alcohol misuse<ref name=":31">{{Cite journal|last=Head|first=M.|last2=Goodwin|first2=L.|last3=Debell|first3=F.|last4=Greenberg|first4=N.|last5=Wessely|first5=S.|last6=Fear|first6=N.
